summary: This is an internal FBI email from August 22, 2019, providing an update on the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It summarizes investigative activities from August 20, 2019, including interviews with MCC inmates and guards, attempts to serve subpoenas, and the execution of search warrants for guard phone records.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The investigation centers on the circumstances surrounding his death while in custody at the MCC.

events.title: FBI interviews MCC inmate regarding document shredding
events.description: FBINY/NYOIG interviewed an MCC inmate regarding possible shredding of Epstein documents. The inmate stated he had no information or knowledge of any suspicious acts or MCC employees shredding documents.

events.title: FBI interviews BOP MCC guards
events.description: FBINY/NYOIG conducted multiple interviews with BOP MCC guards. One guard refused to answer questions and requested an attorney. Another guard, who worked a different shift, was interviewed with no irregularities found. Lieutenant (LT.) was also interviewed but had nothing significant to add.

events.title: Attempt to serve Grand Jury Subpoena
events.description: NYOIG planned to attempt to serve a Federal Grand Jury Subpoena on a BOP MCC guard.

events.title: Search warrants served on phone companies
events.description: FBINY served search warrants on Sprint and Verizon for cellular phones belonging to two MCC Correctional Officers (COs) to obtain Call Detail Records (CDRs) and subscriber information.

events.title: Investigation status update
events.description: An email update indicates plans to possibly retrieve a cellular phone from a BOP MCC Guard, while awaiting the Medical Examiner (ME) report from OCME and financial records on BOP MCC Guards.

keyFacts: The FBI was actively investigating the circumstances of Jeffrey Epstein's death, including potential evidence tampering (shredding of documents).
Multiple Bureau of Prisons (BOP) MCC guards were interviewed; at least one invoked their right to an attorney and refused to answer questions.
Search warrants were executed on Sprint and Verizon to obtain phone records for two MCC Correctional Officers.
The investigation was awaiting the official Medical Examiner's report from the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME).
The email indicates high-level coordination within the FBI's New York office and Criminal Investigative Division regarding the investigation.
